conversation.content: [犹豫] 是你吗，玛丽亚？
[急促吸气] 天啊，我听说你出来了但是没想到——我是说，我不确定你还会不会回这儿来。
[轻声] 说实话，这是我出来后第一个想来的地方。整个街区都变了，就这个小卖部还是老样子。
[声音发颤] 15年了你还记得我的名字。那天早上我亲眼看着他们从停车场把你带走。我们都以为——
[轻声打断] 以为是我干的。大家都这么想。也不怪谁，连我自己的律师一开始都好像认定了是我。[呼气] 那些证据看起来确实很不利。
我女儿现在都上大学了。你以前每周五给她买草莓牛奶的时候，她才刚上幼儿园呢。[更柔和] 她有时候还会问起你。
[怅然] 扎小辫的小索菲亚。都上大学了？外面的时间一直在走，我在里面却像被冻住了一样。
真正的凶手认罪了，对吧？新闻上是这么说的。什么临终前良心发现，供出了三个案子，包括你那个。
[带着苦涩] 是啊，癌症晚期的时候良心发现了。三个无辜的人被关着，他倒是逍遥了十几年。[叹气] 至少我算幸运的，还能活着出来。
[几乎听不见] 罗伯托没撑到？天哪，我记得他妈妈每周都来这儿买汇款单往里面打钱。大概5年前就不来了。
在牢房里心脏病发作，认罪前两年就走了。听说他妈妈没多久也因为伤心过度去世了。
[哽咽] 真的太遗憾了。
你知道我最想念什么吗？就是这种普通的聊天，聊聊天气啊孩子啊，抱怨抱怨物价什么的。监狱里的对话全都围着时间转——服了多久，还剩多久，失去了多久。
[更稳定] 那个，牛奶现在都4块5了，天天都有人来抱怨，这算不算让你找回正常的感觉？[无力的笑] 有些事还真是一点没变。
[干笑] 4块5？我进去的时候才2块钱不到。看来我得再打个官司才买得起菜了。
政府应该给了你赔偿吧？我是说，让你受了这么多苦，总得有个说法吧。
每年冤狱5万块。听起来挺多的，可是想想这钱要买回15年的人生、名誉，还有那些已经向前走的家人。
[温柔地] 你女儿大概半年前来过，问我有没有你案子的消息。她留了电话号码，说万一你回来了就告诉你。[rustling papers vocally] 我一直放在收银台这儿呢。
[声音哽咽] 你一直留着？
[温暖地] 我们有些人从来没放弃过，一直相信你会再走进这个门的。欢迎回家，詹姆斯。今天的草莓牛奶，我请。

original_conversation.content: [hesitant] Is that you, Maria?
[sharp intake of breath] Oh my God, I heard you were out but I didn't think— I mean, I wasn't sure if you'd ever come back here.
[quietly] This was the first place I wanted to visit actually, believe it or not. Everything else in the neighborhood changed but somehow this corner store is exactly the same.
[voice trembling] Fifteen years and you still remember my name. I watched them take you away that morning, right from the parking lot. We all thought—
[gently interrupting] You thought I did it. Everyone did. Can't blame anyone for that when even my own lawyer seemed convinced at first. [exhales] The evidence looked pretty damning.
My daughter's in college now. She was just starting kindergarten when you used to buy her those strawberry milk drinks every Friday. [softer] She asked about you sometimes.
[wistful] Little Sophia with the pigtails. College already? Time kept moving out here while everything stayed frozen for me in there.
The real guy confessed, right? That's what the news said. Some deathbed confession about three different cases including yours.
[bitter edge] Yeah, conscience got to him when the cancer did. Three innocent people locked up while he walked free for over a decade. [sighs] At least I'm the lucky one who survived to see freedom.
[barely audible] Roberto didn't make it? Oh God, I remember his mother coming here every week buying commissary money orders. She stopped coming about five years ago.
Heart attack in his cell, two years before the confession. His mother passed shortly after from grief, they say.
[choked up] I'm so sorry.
You know what I missed most? These normal conversations, talking about weather and kids and complaining about prices. Prison conversations all revolve around time—time served, time left, time lost.
[steadier] Well, milk's four fifty now and everyone complains about it daily if that helps you feel normal again. [weak laugh] Some things really don't change.
[dry laugh] Four fifty? It was barely two dollars when I went away. Maybe I need to file another lawsuit just to afford groceries now.
The state gave you a settlement though, right? I mean, for what they put you through, there must be some compensation.
Fifty thousand per year of wrongful incarceration. Sounds like a lot until you realize it's supposed to buy back fifteen years of your life, your reputation, your family who moved on.

[gently] Your daughter came by here about six months ago, asked if I'd heard anything about your case. She left her number in case you ever came back. [rustling papers vocally] I kept it right here by the register.
[voice breaking] You kept it?
[warmly] Some of us never stopped believing you'd walk through that door again. Welcome home, James. The strawberry milk is on the house today.

scenario: An exonerated person visits the corner store where they used to shop before their wrongful conviction, encountering the same cashier who worked there fifteen years ago.
